text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument now number oh oh seven thirty, Adarand Constructors, Inc.
versus Mineta.
Mr. Pendley.
[Inaudible]
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.
In nineteen eighty-nine, the small family business that is Adarand lost a Federal contract because of a racial program and the race of its owner, Randy Pesh.
In nineteen ninety-five, this Court held that Adarand had standing to seek forward-looking relief because that program prevented it from competing on an equal footing.
In two thousand one, Adarand returns to this Court because it still can't compete on an equal footing.
[Inaudible]

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Pendley,
That...

text_blocks.text: treat, if you will, fairly shortly coming up in your argument, the Government says that in a direct procurement program, these sort of preferences that you're challenging are simply not used in Colorado.
No, Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: challenged those, as I understand it.
Your Honor, Adarand has challenged all manner in which the pro-

No, Your Honor.
In  i-

Compensation clause, Your Honor.

What happened was that the the the district court held that the entire program, all of section eight D of the Sub-Small Business Act, was unconstitutional.
sufficiently.

you just answered my question. You said they...

y- it is not right, Your Honor.

the direct Federal procurement program which remains unchanged.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

you...

We Your Honor, Adarand had challenged consistently first first of all, the subcontracting compensation clause is one mechanism that the United States developed to implement the statutory program that Adarand challenges.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What's the answer to Justice Breyer's question?
That Adarand had standing at that time.

text_blocks.text: No.
What do we do?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: premise was that you had no standing at the time the court of appeals wrote this decision.
I do not, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Okay.

The reason Adarand does not agree with that premise because the Laidlaw decision holds that once Adarand had standing, as a result of this Court's nineteen ninety-five decision, that standing continued until such time as the United States somehow made the case moot as the result of revocation...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I thought Laidlaw stood for the principle that standing is judged as of the time the suit is filed.
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And subsequent changes affect mootness possibly, but not standing.
Yes, Your Honor.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Is that correct?
That's my understanding.
But so what are the the question before the Court...
on the issue...

Conclude that the Tenth Circuit was wrong in stating what it stated in that footnote because Adarand specifically challenged eight D four.

text_blocks.text: Well, you raised it, but you surely didn't address it.

Well, what what Adarand addressed was the const- at the Tenth Circuit was the constitutionality of this of this racial program, and and there are a number of mechanisms by which the ran- racial program is implemented against Adarand.

It is one of the mechanisms by which the United States continues to implement this this regime, this program.

may I finish this? I'm I apologize.
Court   -- I'm sorry Your Honor.

text_blocks.text: ask m- what is i- very important, I think, in this in this case? And and you seem to be walking to away from it.
I'm apologize.

text_blocks.text: This Court is a court of review.
Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Not a court of first view.

Your Honor, the the controversy Adarand presents in two thousand one is that Adarand still is unable to compete on an equal footing because the United States still has in its tool of in its tool kit mechanisms by which it is applying this racial preference against Adarand.
Mr. Pendley...

Yes.

Absolutely, Your Honor.
first rea-

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: provisions of the statute that you challenge are unconstitutional.

Well, under strict scrutiny, the Court must start, as Croson dictates, with the question, has is there a strong basis in evidence of a compelling governmental interest? Congress declined this Court's invitation, and generous invitation, in nineteen ninety-five to provide that.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Your first point is that the congressional findings are inadequate.

General Olson,

and may it please the Court.

usual.

study. so...

Well, why wouldn't the why wouldn't the contractor...

This case...

that they ever have.

memorandum...

text_blocks.text: Lands Highway Division engineers.
Well, Justice Scalia, it strikes me and I I respectfully submit that that you're switching it around.
Do you think that for a single minute if...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: these clauses required racial discrimination, an absolute clear, patent violation of the Fourteenth Amendment, that we would say there's no standing for a minority who wanted these removed? Not for a single minute.

Well, I'm I I wouldn't contradict that, but I would say when the Government has made it absolutely clear that it is not enforcing race-conscious remedies, as instructed by this Court in in the first Adarand decision, except in in a narrowly tailored fashion, there's been subsequent legislation of a compelling need, but that that response to that compelling need has been narrowed down to the areas where it is necessary...

in those areas...

under. It was...

you a cite to the record, but the ind- the the i- the the Department of Justice memoranda is in the Government's appendix.

not have applied in nineteen eighty-nine when this case first arose.
Well wha- why is it...

any application...

important to emphasize that this is a facial challenge to the statute and to the system.
Salerno case.

text_blocks.text: what what's a what's a facial challenge in in this context? I mean, it seems to me a lot of the questioning here and to a- Adarand's counsel has been to show that Adarand was directly affected by the thing.
I I respectfully disagree with respect to whether Adarand was adversely affected by the program.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, they certainly in in the case we first we first decided, the nineteen ninety-five case we decided that they they they were sufficiently affected, so we ruled.
Yes, and they were affected by the we're not contending that they did not have standing to challenge that subcontracting...
compensation provision.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

Yes.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Which now has been found to be...
unconstitutional.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: And it's out of the picture.
That's correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: But now we have a new set of arguments basically.

Yes, and and to the extent that that the th- the the program, as it exists, requires people to in order to be designated as a disadvantaged business enter- enterprise, must file certificates articulating that they have been the victim of a social and economic disadvantage.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

Well, it's defined in...
the statute.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Yeah, absolutely.

It's it's it's explained in the statute both with respect to ethnic and racial prejudice because of their identi- identity as a group without regard to individual qualities, and that economic disadvantage the ability to compete in the free enterprise system has diminished capital and credit opportunities as compared to others in the same business area...
one of those...

would would be quite...

Both get well, is- that's a social the us- the use of the term in the statute described a victim of of prejudice or bias, and that has had economic effect on the individual.
in...

No.

form?
is not the right form.

the the different States use different forms.

text_blocks.text: But apparently what what the agency proposed proposed on May eighth, two thousand and one simply says, I hereby certify that I am a member of one of the following groups you check the minority group and that I have held myself out as a member of that group.

Right?

but the but the but the but that has to be looked at in terms of the what the statute defines as social and economic disadvantage and what the regulations, which are in in at pages seventy to seventy-two A of the Government's appendix, which define which which are the regulation Department of Transportation regulations.
agency...

text_blocks.text: one go about rebutting it? I mean, who could rebut it and how would you go...
about it?
Any adversely affected party can rebut it.
In fact...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

would you have...

text_blocks.text: to show to rebut it?

Well, what you have to show to be entitled to certification, according to the regulations, is substantial and chronic social disadvantage in the business world and that s- and that credit has been impaired due to diminished capital or opportunities have been impaired due to diminished capital and credit opportunities, as compared to others in the same or similar line of business.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Social disadvantage in the business world.
Social and i- social disadvantage, Justice Scalia, is defined in the statute as having been a victim of racial or or or prejudice of that nature, and that ha- it has produced economic disadvantage...
You say just...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: two opposite things on this economic disadvantage.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: understand that...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You say in your brief that they ha- you have to sign an affidavit that says my ability to compete in the free enterprise system has been impaired due to diminished capital and credit opportunities.
Well, I I I believe that we're correct.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's the right answer.
And I hope I said it persuasively.
were...

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States
roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: your point, to be absolutely explicit, is if you are below the at- the plateau, seven hundred and fifty thousand, you still might not qualify as being economically disadvantaged.
That's correct.

Well, I I submit that when you if you were to describe different people of different national backgrounds or racial backgrounds that have been guilty of discrimination, they may fall in any one of those categories.

Well first...

that's weird.

what what the Congress said over and over again, on on the basis of detailed analytical studies which are which are described in considerable detail on the in the court of appeals opinion, and what this Court has said is that there has been the lingering effects, unfortunately, of publicly financed discrimination in the construction industry.
